utterances: No, that's actually - it's in the actual recipe during the final rise when you braid it.

I'm ready to have you take it out of our old family oven, which has seen better days.

You know what the smell reminds me of?
Did you ever have - did your mom or grandmother ever make pie crusts?
You know, when pie crusts would be left over - and pies were made a lot in this house - my grandmother would sugar the crust, the extra crust...
With cinnamon...
...with cinnamon...
Mm-hmm.
...and sugar, and then we kids would just eat these pie sticks.
Sounds a lot like my grandmother's peach kuchen.
She obviously used cardamom in it when she made it.

It's always good to let it rest for 10, 15 minutes before you cut.
Mmm.
It's great.
The one little trick we discovered while playing with this is add a little sweetness to it, either a honey butter or we have nice little jams there, preserves.
It brings out the cardamom just a hair more.
This is really, really good bread.
I just want to say, anyone would enjoy this.
Dean Schmitz, I really want to thank you for being such a good sport.
Thank you for having me.
I think I'm going to have to dig up some more of the Lunts' recipes and do a little bit more playing around.
When you go to our Web site, to find out how to make Swedish cardamom bread, check out Alfred Lunt's coffee recipe, which uses a whole egg.
Our story on the Lunts at Ten Chimneys airs tomorrow on ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.

Now the recollections and reflections of children five years after September 11.
Back in 2001, a small group of Washington, D.C., private school students just barely into their teens were asked by a classmate to record their reactions to the terrorist attacks.
This year, the young woman who made that recording has gone back through it, sharing some selections with the others.
Here are their thoughts and hers.
Testing.
Hello.
My name is Emily Mason and I'm going to do a short interview of seven kids from my school in Washington, D.C.
I'm doing them because of something that just happened.
See, there's been this horrible event.
They are getting ready for the day when we are no longer there.
Mellencamp made a musical journey for his album ""No Better Than This."" He made this recording at the Sun Studio in Memphis.
He stood in the room where great African American blues singers once recorded, as did the young Johnny Cash and Elvis Presley.

There was an X on the floor where Elvis stood, there was an X where the drum kit was set up, there was an X where the upright bass was supposed to go, and there was an X where the guitar was supposed to go, and the microphone goes in the middle.
And so that's what we did.
When you hear it, it's just like - well, there's no doubt where you're at - you're in Sun Studios.
(Soundbite of song, ""Each Day of Sorrow"")
(Singing) So all of you angels, don't waste your words.
Dog-gone my soul, I ain't no good...
The Indiana singer has been touring with Bob Dylan, which is the sort of thing that would get a musician thinking about tradition.
As old school as this music sounds, Mellencamp would have like to make it sound older.
My original idea was to record on a lathe, but of course they can't...
(Soundbite of laughter)
Really, yeah right.
Well, I wanted to go straight to disc.
You're talking about the wax discs on which people did some of the earliest recordings.
Yes.
Is that what you're saying?
Yeah.
Just make it old fashioned.
Yeah, that was the original idea.
That became very problematic because, you know, you couldn't find the material, there was a whole bunch of problems.
So I said, well, let's go to the next best thing.
Let's find what they recorded on out in the field.
(Soundbite of music)
He's referring to the researchers who famously recorded old Southern musicians decades ago.
(Soundbite of song, ""Thinking About You"")
(Singing) It's not in my nature to be nostalgic at all.
I sat by the phone last night waiting for you to call.
Mellencamp traveled around with old reel-to-reel tape machines from the 1950s.
He brought his band to an old Texas hotel, where the 1920s bluesman Robert Johnson once recorded.
He even recorded at a historic black church in Savannah, Georgia.
Because of the simple recording, producer T-Bone Burnett had no way to mix the sound of different instruments, or different versions of a song.
They just had to be right.
There's no, you know, half of this song here, and half of that song there.
Everything was one take.
Every performance was the way it was played, from beginning to end.
T-Bone and I both laughed at I said, T-Bone, what the hell were we doing in the '80s?
(Soundbite of laughter)
Why did we record these songs over and over and over and over again?
When I was a kid I recorded the song ""Hurt So Good."" And we cut that track a hundred times, but first of all because we couldn't play and we never could get the rhythm to work.
And you know, so we just kept playing it, da, dun, dun, dun, we couldn't get that part right, you know, so we just kept over dubbing and playing and over it.
And it was like, I would never, as an adult make a record like that again after this experience.
Why?
Because this was so much more musical and so much more fun than actually - of course, we can play now, too.
That helps.
(Soundbite of song, ""Save Some Time To Dream"")
(Singing) Save some time to dream.
Save some time for yourself.
Don't let your time slip away or be stolen by somebody else.
One of my colleagues here was listening to this song, ""Save Some Time to Dream,"" and to the lyrics - which you seem to be advising someone not to let all your time fly by.
And it brought to mind a much earlier song of yours, a hit song, ""Jack and Diane,"" in which there's a description of almost too much time.
Life goes on, long after the thrill of living is gone.
Do you think your ideas about time and about life have changed as you've gotten a little older?
Well, you know, the older you get, the more you realize that wow, you know, I'm burning through these years pretty quickly.
And I know there's times that I look back on my early recording career and I really wasted my time.
My ego and my drive and my tenacity was so strong, as a young man, that, you know, we had to just punch, you know, our way through.
So any accomplishment that we may have had back then was lost on me.
You never paused to savor it, you're saying?
No, I didn't - I never cared about it.
I could have cared less.
Don't misunderstand me.
I'm not complaining.
I would bet my bottom dollar I had more fun in that same time period than most people are allowed to have in their life.
But at the same time, you know, I didn't take time to enjoy the success that we were having.
That's how John Mellencamp remembers the 1980's.
In these latest recordings, in three different locations, you can say he took time to immerse himself in tradition.
(Soundbite of song, ""Love At First Sight"")
